This page is about TypeScript code basics.

Results bellow code blocks are generated dynamically from "main.js" script file, which means that all the code examples provided are functioning properly for sure. More or less, the only difference in code blocks at html page are "console.log" statements vs "innerHTML" method at source code "main.ts" file needed for printing results at web page.

Be free to look up the source code file "main.ts" at GitHub page.


Content:

1.2 Multi type variables

2. Arrays

8.1 Switch values

1. Variables and data types


      const title: string = "TypeScript Basics";
      const myAge: number = 43;
      const canVote: boolean = true;
      let anything: any = "dog";
      anything = 2;

      console.log(`const title is a ${typeof (title)}`);
      console.log(`const myAge is a ${typeof (myAge)}`);
      console.log(`const canVote is a ${typeof (canVote)}`);
      console.log(`let anything is a ${typeof (anything)}`);


1.1 Converting string variables to number and vise versa


      let strToNum: number = parseInt("5");
      let numToStr: number = 5;

      console.log(`strToNum is a ${typeof (strToNum)}`);
      console.log(`numToStr is a ${typeof (numToStr.toString())}`);


1.2 Multi type variables


      let multiType: number | boolean; // either variable calls are ok
      multiType = 20;
      multiType = true;

      console.log(multiType);


2. Arrays


      let employees1: string[] = ["Bob", "Sally", "Sam"]; // One way of array declaration
      let employees2: Array = ["John", "Harry", "Ava"]; // Another way of array declaration

      console.log(employees1);
      console.log(employees2);


2.1 Tuple arrays (arrays with multiple types)


      let employees3: [string, number] = ["Megan", 8];

      console.log(employees3);


2.2 Enum


      enum Color { Red = 5, Green, Blue }
      let c: Color = Color.Green; // will print the index value of Green color, which is 6 in this case

      console.log(c);


3. Math


      let addition = 5 + 4;
      let subtraction = 5 - 4;
      let multiplication = 5 * 4;
      let division = 5 / 4;
      let modulo = 5 % 4;

      console.log(addition);
      console.log(subtraction);
      console.log(multiplication);
      console.log(division);
      console.log(modulo);


4. Looping


      let randArray = [1, "john", false];

      for (let i in randArray) { // "in" will print array indexes
        ...
      }
      for (let i of randArray) { // "of" will print array values
        ...
      }

      console.log(randArray);

5. Functions


      let getSum = function (num1: number, num2: number): number {
        return num1 + num2;
      }
      
      let theSum1: number = getSum(5, 2);
      
      let getDiff = function (num1: number, num2 = 2, num3?: number): number { // num3 parameter is optional
        if (typeof num3 !== "undefined") {
          return num1 - num2 - num3;
        }
        return num1 - num2;
      }

      console.log(theSum1);
      console.log(getDiff(5)); // Number value "2" is already defined in the function as num2 parameter!
      console.log(getDiff(5, 2, 3));

    5.1 Arrow function

    
      let addOne = (n: number): number => n + 1;

      console.log(addOne(8));

      5.2 Generic functions with data type markers

      
      function GetTypeOf(value: T): string {
        return typeof (value);
      }
        
      let aString = "A string";
      let aNumber = 10;

      console.log(GetTypeOf(aString));
      console.log(GetTypeOf(aNumber));

        5.3 Spread operator

        
      // Typed spread operator works only when all parameters are marked as optional
      function theSum(x?: number, y?: number, z?: number): number {
        return x + y + z;
      }

      let args = [4, 5, 6];

      console.log(`Sum: ${theSum(...args)}`);

          6. Interfaces

          
      interface SuperHero {
        realName: String;
        superName: String;
      }

      let superman: SuperHero = {
        realName: "Clark Kent",
        superName: "Superman"
      }

      let superHeroes: SuperHero[] = [];

      superHeroes.push({
        realName: "Bruce Wayne",
        superName: "Batman"
      });

      console.log(`${superman.realName} is ${superman.superName}`);
      console.log(`${superHeroes[0].realName} is ${superHeroes[0].superName}`);

            7. Classes

            
      class Animal {
        public favFood: string;
        static numOfAnimals: number = 0;

        constructor(private name: string, private owner: string) {
          Animal.numOfAnimals++;
        }

        ownerInfo() {
          console.log(`${this.name} is owned by ${this.owner}`)
        }

        static howManyAnimals(): number {
          return Animal.numOfAnimals;
        }

        private _weight: number;

        get weight(): number {
          return this._weight;
        }

        set weight(weight: number) {
          this._weight = weight;
        }
      }

      let spot = new Animal("Spot", "Doug");

      spot.ownerInfo();
      spot.weight = 100;

      console.log(`Spot's weight is ${spot.weight}`)
      console.log(`Number of Animals: ${Animal.howManyAnimals()}`)

            7.1 Class inheritance (subclasses)

            
      class Dog extends Animal {
        constructor(name: string, owner: string) {
          super(name, owner);
          Dog.numOfAnimals++
        }
      }

      let grover = new Dog("Grover", "Jimmy");

      console.log(`Is a Dog an Animal: ${grover instanceof Animal}`);
      console.log(`Does Grover have a name: ${"name" in grover}`);
      console.log(`Does Grover have an owner: ${"owner" in grover}`);
      console.log(`Number of Animals is now: ${Animal.howManyAnimals()}`);

              7.2 Class interface example

              
      interface Vehicle {
        drive(): any;
      }

      class Car implements Vehicle {
        constructor(private wheels: number) { }
        drive(): void {
          let carWheels = document.querySelector(".car");
          carWheels.innerText = `The car drives with ${this.wheels} wheels`;
          
          let carWheels2 = document.querySelector(".car2");
          carWheels2.innerText = `The car drives with ${this.wheels} wheels`;
        }
      }
          
      class Bicycle implements Vehicle {
        constructor(private wheels: number) { }
        drive(): void {
          let bicycleWheels = document.querySelector(".bicycle");
          bicycleWheels.innerText = `The car drives with ${this.wheels} wheels`;

          let bicycleWheels2 = document.querySelector(".bicycle2");
          bicycleWheels2.innerText = `The car drives with ${this.wheels} wheels`;
        }
      }

      // Please notice:
      // There is "HTMLElement tag with angle brackets" before all "document.querySelector()" statements.
      // Code highligh library omit that tag from some reasons. You can look at source code for exact syntax.
          
      let car = new Car(4);
      let bike = new Bicycle(2);

      car.drive();
      bike.drive();

              7.2.1 Example with data type markers

              
      function GetWheels(veh: w): number {
        return veh.drive();
      }
      
      GetWheels(car);
      GetWheels(bike);

              7.3 Generic classes

              
      class GenericTypeValue {
        add: (val1: T, val2: T) => T;
      }

      let newNumber = new GenericTypeValue();

      newNumber.add = function (x, y) {
        return x + y;
      }

      let newString = new GenericTypeValue();
        
      newString.add = function (x, y) {
        return String(Number(x) + Number(y));
      }
        
      console.log(`5 + 4 = ${newNumber.add(5, 4)}`)
      console.log(`5 + 6 = ${newString.add("5", "6")}`)

                8. Destructuring (multiple values in one line)

                
      let multiValues = { x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 };
      let { x, y, z } = multiValues;

      console.log(`${x + y + z}`);

                  8.1 Switch values

                  
      let multiValues = { x: 1, y: 2, z: 3 };
      let { x, y, z } = multiValues;

      [x, y, z] = [z, y, x];

      console.log(`${x}${y}${z}`);
